messages.message:
Brian
Thank you for the connect!

Brian
I just leveled up.  I love physics.  Can I ask you something I've been wondering for a while?
Yes

Brian
If I was in the 3rd dimension traveling at the speed of light, and everything I see would look two dimensional because the light around we would looked stationary.  How would I perceive the 3rd dimension if everything looks flat?  Faster than light?  What does a shadow look like when moving faster than light?

Brian
What are you thinking?
Well... Our Universe has more than 3 dimensions. Nothing can travel faster than light (Lorentz) except across quantum tunnels (Cassini effect).

Brian
Brilliant, this is new information and just what I needed.
Excuse me for my poor description... But I've studied physics in France and I think in French when I talk about physics

Brian
I might know something you don't know about physics   I know of something that travels faster than time.
You're a genius to me BTW.
Time don't travel... And time depends on the density of energy at the concrete point of measuring

Brian
Brilliant!  There is a lot of understanding for me there.  Love transcends time, your love of physics has made me so much smarter than you can even imagine.  You just saved me 4 years of college education in 20 minutes.  See what I mean?
Nope

Brian
Everything you have worked for is to answer a really hard question.  If I study this and comprehend the hardest question I can think of, that saves me time learning all the easy stuff I already know.
You need to start with the "easy" stuff to grow up

Brian
I agree.  I took physics in college.  I want to know the end of that so I can study it from the beginning.  I think a lot of this is happening backwards.  Once I see the end, I start to realize the paths to get there.
Physics Sciences are a marathon... You can't stop learning.

Brian
What else should I learn?

What are of Physics?
*AREA

Brian
How do you measure love?
Love is chemistry... My knowledge about biochemistry is limited.

Brian
We have to study other fields to gain universal understanding. This is called interleaving.

Brian
Can I give you another example I just though of?
Yes

Brian
The fridge has 1 cold drink.  I put more drinks in the fridge to cool them down.  When the door closes, the fridge contains both cold and warmer drinks.  If I put the cold drink in the front, the next person gets a cold drink instead of a warm one.  Saving time and making them happy, (assuming they like cold drinks).  How do you measure what I did?  Moving the cold drink to the front so the next person enjoys it?  Productivity is a measurement tool we can apply to the entire human race to understand human physics.
